Choose a status based on use case
Variant Use it for
Available When item is available for purchase.
Low availability When item is available for purchase but it will probably be unavailable in a short period of time.
Unavailable When item is not available for purchase because it's out of stock.
Indeterminate When a product is not available for purchase for reasons other than out of stock or if it is not possible to determine
its status.
Choose a size and scale it based on the label size
To balance good glanceability with flexibility to use indicator in compact spaces, two
size variants are provided: Small and Proportional.
¢ Small size should be used with text under 14px.
¢ Proportional size should be used with text of 14px and above, and should scale in
proportion to that label. The proportional indicator is 40% of the label font size with a
minimum of 12px diameter.

Always present a descriptive label
Status should always display a label that describes the current state and its object. Be
sure to have enough space for both label and indicator, and also to position the
indicator so it's visually connected to the label.

Status indicators can influence user journeys
Different statuses can trigger different feelings for customers. While a low availability
status can make users feel an urgency to buy that product, an unavailable one can
prevent them from even clicking on a product to learn more.

Presenting Status of multiple services at once
Always separate and inform up-front different services with their unique status
information. An item can be available for pickup at one store but unavailable for
delivery to a specific address. Mixing Status together can surprise users negatively later
in the sales funnel.
